headline: Four Months After First Case, U.S. Death Toll Passes 100,000
snippet: For renters who’ve survived financially with help from the government and laws barring eviction, time is running out. Despite analysts’ forecasts, investors keep pushing the stock market higher.
abstract: Scientists are revising the timeline of how the virus spread. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos said she would direct public school districts to share federal aid with private schools.

headline: Trump Suggests Virus Death Count Is Inflated. Most Experts Doubt It
snippet: The numbers, some officials say, include too many “presumed” cases. But even Dr. Anthony Fauci said that the overall toll was likely an undercount.
abstract: Senior White House and health officials have sought new ways to find the extent of infections and deaths, questioning whether official counts are inflating the toll of the virus.
byline: By Noah Weiland, Maggie Haberman and Abby Goodnough

headline: Fauci to Warn Senate of ‘Needless Suffering and Death’
snippet: President Trump made misleading statements on testing; inmates in Los Angeles County tried to infect themselves, jail officials said. Here’s the latest.
abstract: The risks of reopening the country too soon will be a focus of government hearings on Tuesday. The White House’s new mask requirement won’t apply to President Trump.

headline: Top Health Officials to Quarantine After Being Exposed
snippet: The virus has cost President Trump seniors’ support. The F.D.A. approved the first antigen test that can rapidly detect the virus.
abstract: Three children have died of a mysterious syndrome linked to the virus. Trump’s support among seniors slips as the pandemic becomes more political.

headline: F.D.A. Clears First Home Saliva Test; Pence’s Press Secretary Has Virus
snippet: The latest federal data revealed 20.5 million jobs lost in April, and unemployment rivaling the Great Depression.New York City, Los Angeles and Chicago are the primary generators of new coronavirus cases each day. President Trump will be tested daily after a valet fell ill.
abstract: The U.S. lost 20.5 million jobs in April, the worst devastation since the Great Depression. Flaws in the Paycheck Protection Program could leave small-business owners saddled with debt.

headline: White House Rejects C.D.C.’s Coronavirus Reopening Plan
snippet: The agency’s detailed guidelines for reopening were blocked from publication after Trump administration officials labeled them “overly prescriptive.”
abstract: Detailed guidelines for reopening drafted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention were blocked from publication after Trump administration officials labeled them “overly prescriptive.”
byline: By Abby Goodnough and Maggie Haberman

headline: Trump Says Task Force Will Wind Down
snippet: President Trump said the group would be replaced by “something in a different form,” despite grim projections for the months ahead.
abstract: Jared Kushner tried to address a looming supply shortage with volunteers from the private sector. More than 1,000 people have died each day for over a month. Meat is growing scarcer.

headline: Models Project Sharp Rise in Deaths as States Reopen
snippet: Tensions between Washington and Beijing escalated as President Trump said the U.S. death toll could reach 100,000. The Supreme Court will hear cases remotely for the first time.
abstract: An internal Trump administration report expects about 200,000 daily cases by June. The White House bars coronavirus task force officials from testifying to Congress without approval.

headline: As More States Reopen, Protesters Chafe at Restrictions
snippet: More than half of U.S. states moved to reopen businesses. Armed protesters entered the Capitol in Michigan. The C.D.C. announced an initiative to speed virus research.
abstract: The F.D.A. issued emergency approval for an antiviral drug. High school seniors appear reluctant to commit to a college for the fall.

headline: Trump Bans Travel From Brazil, Citing Pandemic
snippet: The N.B.A. said it might restart its suspended season in late July at a Florida resort.
abstract: As the United States marked the Memorial Day weekend, President Trump golfed, some Americans flocked to beaches and the death toll neared 100,000. And in Britain, the prime minister said he would not fire an aide for driving across the country while infected.

headline: ‘Jaw-Dropping’ Fraud Reported as Jobless Claims Reach 38.6 Million
abstract: President Trump, visiting a Michigan factory, again refused to wear a mask in public. Flags were ordered lowered for Memorial Day weekend in memory of those who died from the virus.

headline: House Passes $3 Trillion Relief Bill Seen as Democrats’ Opening Bid
snippet: A $3 trillion package would include billions for struggling states but has been criticized as a “blue-state bailout” by Republican leaders. A test used on White House personnel might not be accurate, the F.D.A. said.
abstract: Beaches in New York and other states in the region can open for Memorial Day weekend. Many retail workers have reluctantly turned into de facto enforcers of public health guidelines.

headline: Wisconsin Supreme Court Strikes Down Stay-at-Home Order
snippet: Millions more U.S. residents left their homes this week, according to a New York Times analysis. Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said that reopening too quickly risked “an outbreak that you may not be able to control.”
abstract: President Trump pushes to reopen schools, and criticizes Dr. Fauci’s warnings about moving too quickly. The administration weighs extending some border restrictions indefinitely.

headline: Relaxed Rules and Warm Weather Test States
snippet: As states reopen, warmer weather is luring people outdoors and clashes are flaring over restrictions.
abstract: Congress declined the administration’s offer of rapid testing, saying tests were needed more elsewhere. Former President George W. Bush urged unity in a video message.

headline: As Restrictions Lift, Countries Brace for a New Reality
snippet: The virus appears to be spreading swiftly in Kabul. The death toll in Italy surpassed 28,000.
abstract: As lockdowns begin to ease for millions of Europeans, Italy reports a spike in deaths. Migrants face roundups in Malaysia and surging infections in Singapore’s dormitories.

headline: As Hot Spots Shift, Pandemic Enters a New Phase
snippet: Falling numbers in some of the hardest-hit places in the United States have offered signs of hope. But infections and deaths are rising elsewhere.
abstract: Some Americans face economic ruin with government aid set to end. Masks become a flash point for businesses, and the C.D.C. proposes changes that would remake the workplace.

headline: As Death Toll Nears 100,000, Some in White House Question the Math
snippet: The United States continues its advance toward 100,000 deaths, a grim milestone the country is expected to reach in the coming days. Here’s the latest.
abstract: President Trump ordered states to reopen places of worship, but several governors said that decision would be their call. Persistently high case levels in Los Angeles, Chicago and Washington have medical experts concerned.

headline: Did de Blasio Bungle the Crisis?
snippet: Opinion columnists discuss how New York handled the coronavirus crisis.
abstract: And has the coronavirus ended food culture as we know it?

headline: Lockdown Delays Led to at Least 36,000 More Deaths, Models Find
snippet: Connecticut’s stay-at-home-order lifts today, making it one of the last states to return to business. C.D.C. guidance, rejected by the White House, is released.
abstract: All 50 states have begun to reopen to some degree, but rules vary. Scientists say they see progress on the path to developing a vaccine by next year.

headline: When the Mask You’re Wearing ‘Tastes Like Socialism’
snippet: The partisan divide over how to respond to the coronavirus pandemic has deepened over the past few weeks.
abstract: The partisan divide over how to respond to the coronavirus pandemic has deepened over the past few weeks.

headline: All 50 States Have Eased Coronavirus Restrictions
snippet: President Trump gave the organization 30 days to “commit to substantive improvements.” Mr. Trump also said he was taking hydroxychloroquine, an unproven drug against the coronavirus, as a preventive measure.
abstract: More changes took effect on Wednesday, but vast discrepancies remain as states forge ahead after shutdowns. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin warns of “permanent damage” to the economy.

headline: Trump Threatens to Leave W.H.O. and Permanently End Funding
snippet: As states ease restrictions, public health experts warned of a resurgence of the virus if the authorities move too fast. The Fed chief said the economy would not fully recover until there was a vaccine.
abstract: The president said the organization had made missteps during the pandemic that “have been extremely costly for the world.” A claim he takes hydroxychloroquine was criticized by doctors.

headline: How Many Covid Deaths? Don’t Ask President Trump
snippet: The president has expressed skepticism about the fatality figures reported to him by his own experts.
abstract: The president has expressed skepticism about the fatality figures reported to him by his own experts.
